content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The question is creative and is great for all modes. It was fun solving it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I find the concept interesting, in reverse mode, fastest or shortest mode!
You can maybe add in constraints : length of “key”  = number of words in “message”?
The author was able to listen to the advice of other Codingamers to improve his proposal :D

Nice puzzle! I did it in reverse mode and it is simple and fast to solve.
For now I would approve it for reverse mode.
However for shortest mode, you should make your statement clearer because this can be solved in a very short time (less than 1min for good players in fastest) and statement has to be very clear and concise.
Example:
You must decode a [[message]] using a [[key]] composed of digits.
For each digit <<d>> in [[key]] with <<i>> the index of <<d>>: if <<d>> is strictly greater than zero, print  the <<dth>> character of <<ith>> word of [[message]].

It is important for your players to have several ways to solve this problem. The reverse mode is very cool and the fastest and shortest modes only need a clearer statement. :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it, it's actually Reverse Mode in all three modes.... but the statement clearly describes this quirk ;)

I liked this clash and I think it's perfect for reverse mode,
coz taking a look on all the inputs you can figure out how to solve that problem.  As for fastest mode I dont recommend it too coz just one input/output example isn't enough for solving.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Unfortunately this clash, which is a good idea, is basically impossible in fastest and shortest mode since you need more than one of the test cases to solve it.
Cool problem, but I think the statement should be more clear. I was only able to understand it after looking at all test cases. Or is it intended that part of the problem is to figure out what to do?

Thanks! 

And yes, it is intended for the participants to figure out how to find out the hidden word. 

Maybe I should phrase it better to make it known that the participants have to find out how to figure out the hidden word themselves.

Thanks for the feedback!

But isn't the test cases visible for both fastest and shortest?

If I interpreted correctly, you would prefer to have a clear instruction on how to convert the input to output, without looking at the test cases.

Unfortunately that's not what I have intended for this clash. It's more like a puzzle game than an instruction manual. Sometime you just have to look at the big picture to find an answer.

Maybe I should add that statement in for the intention. Thanks!

Thanks for the feedback!

I'm honestly curious though, did you know that you can see all test cases in all 3 modes? Or are there any reasons, that you will insist only investigate what is shown to you?

If there are many people who didn't know that, then I may consider reducing it to just reverse mode.
Thanks for the approval!

I totally agree with you !

Once these changes made, I would be happy to approve this contribution !

(you can answer to my message so I get a notification to approve your contribution :D)
Thanks for the approval and the feedbacks!
Thanks for the approval!

Thanks for the awesome detailed feedback, Ponoran!

I guess its very hard to disguise a reverse mode in other modes, and I realised that it may not be a good thing, after all these comments.

Thanks Pauloux!

I have made the changed with Ponoran's suggestion in mind.

I think the explanation is not very clear:

1- The length of the key is 1:1 to the length of the message.
2- Each digit in the key represent the position of each word in the message

I think you can replace this by something like:
1- There are as many digits in the key as there are words in the message.
And then like Ponoran said:
2- For each digit <<d>> in [[key]] with <<i>> the index of <<d>>: if <<d>> is strictly greater than zero, print  the <<dth>> character of <<ith>> word of [[message]].

I think it is important to clarify that the number 0 does not represent any letter (with the "if <<d>> is strictly greater than 0")

Moreover, it is important to say that positions given are one-based indexing, so keep it!

PS: I can't do less than 92 characters in Python

I have updated the description, and added with an example.
Hopefully it's more clearer now.

I'm a novice when it comes to python, but i was able to get it down to 80, after doing some research.
It even beat the best I can do with ruby, which is 82.

Python:
print("".join([y[int(x)-1]for x,y in zip(input(),input().split()) if int(x)>0]))

Ruby:
puts gets.chars.map(&:to_i).zip(gets.split).reject{_1[0]==0}.map{|x,y|y[x-1]}.join
Yeah I'm a beginner ! I barely know zip method and I don't know how to use it. GG!

Sure I know I can see all of test cases in every mode =)
Though in fastest and shortest modes in 99% cases I can easily understand from given example whats going on there=)
For example in Hey Hi test case Im afraid I could not figure it out, but second test (How are you) looks more suitable for possible example, I guessed a whole lot easier.
So maybe just changing existing example can do a lot in this situation.

Hmm, I think I'm going to take Ponoran's suggestion, and make it clearer in the description, instead of making it like a puzzle for fastest and shortest. Since there are more people doesn't agrees to that direction I'm going for.

And Dyd is right that its actually just reverse mode in all 3 modes haha.

I will try to see if I can swap the tests around or think of a better one. If not, I hope the updated description will be clearer.

Thanks again for the feedbacks!

Sorry for not responding faster. In fastest and shortest mode, you can only see the first test case, which I don't believe is enough to figure out the pattern. Reverse mode is the only mode in which you can see all of the test cases.

No worries! You have no obligation for that.

Actually you can see all test cases in all modes.
For fastest and shortest, there's a button in the top right corners of the test cases window. I always use that to analyse what problem i have to solve. 

Hmm, I assumed the first 2 tests (excluding the validators) should have been enough to notice the pattern as they are very short. Like the amount of digits is the same as the amount of words.

Test 3 and 4 are to throw the participants off, with a twist from the first 2 tests, which then they learn the words to ignore.

I didn't realize that you could see all of the tests! Sorry! I would add a hint in the instructions on how to see all of the tests, that way people don't spend too much time trying to figure it out based on the statement, and anyone who doesn't know about that feature can still solve the puzzle.
Yeah, that make sense. Thanks!

I like this clash, but I think that if the intention is for participants to find how to use the key based on the test cases, this should be specifically for reverse, as that it the point of reverse mode. Although, I do still think this would be a great clash for other modes if the statement explained how to use the key.

hmm... If I were to explained on how to use the key, I think this clash will become too easy. And its probably more fun to find the solution during the process, instead of feeding the solution to them.
Well, I would still get rid of the mode other than reverse for this clash then.
Thanks for the input. I will wait for more opinions on it, before I make changes to that.
